data.text: @tjlschneider @bigjatyeg @CityofEdmonton @coffee_outside Makes sense, though you could think of it like a morning exercise routine!

@vijamsonic @bigjatyeg @CityofEdmonton @coffee_outside Yes. I’ve thought about going but I work from home and it’s never made sense for me to ride there and then ride back home to work. I don’t commute, just ride my bicycle to get errands done, visit friends, etc.

@tjlschneider @bigjatyeg @CityofEdmonton It’s great! Time wise for me, as it’s short trip to the UofA, it takes less time than driving and requires a modest bundling and good gloves/face protection. On lanes it will be easier!
@vijamsonic @bigjatyeg @CityofEdmonton I e never ridden in the winter before, but I’m emboldened by the bike grid and I’m going to give it a try. Should be interesting!
@tjlschneider @bigjatyeg @CityofEdmonton And my guess would be more than double that for off-grid trips. My commute to work is off the grid.

@bigjatyeg @vijamsonic @CityofEdmonton Hi James, where are you getting your data from? According to data released by the City of Edmonton, the median daily trips by winter cyclists on the bike grid was 1009 last year.
@vijamsonic @CityofEdmonton I see the farmers market blocked it at the intersection with their signs again too.
@vijamsonic @CityofEdmonton Either or , clearing a bike lane for the 5 people that bike in the winter is not good use of my money
@vijamsonic @CityofEdmonton I want my tax dollars spent on clearing roadways not bike lanes #yeg
